items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  12.01
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation and/or Discussion Regarding Avid Program
	 
AVID, Advancement Via Individual Determination, is a college readiness system for elementary through higher education that is designed to increase schoolwide learning and performance. The AVID College Readiness System (ACRS) accelerates student learning, uses research based methods of effective instruction, provides meaningful and motivational professional learning, and acts as a catalyst for systemic reform and change.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item:  12.02
		 
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Presentation and/or Discussion regarding Assembly Bill 9 (or Seth's Law) Anti-Bullying Service Delivery Model
		 
		 
The issue of bullying has plagued many school systems across the nation. We have all read about issues of bullying causing students to take drastic measures to escape the pain. Unfortunately, many of these drastic measures have resulted in suicide and/or murder.  Bullying is also linked to many negative outcomes including impacts on mental health and substance use.
		 
East Side Union High School District is committed to each student’s success in learning within a caring, responsive, and safe environment that is free of discrimination, intimidation, harassment and bullying.  On June 21, 2012, Board Policy 5131 Students – Conduct was amended and Board Policy 5131.2 Students – Bullying was adopted to comply with updated legislation, Assembly Bill 9. Board Policy 5131.2 Students – Bullying includes information on prevention, intervention and the process for handling complaints of bullying and cyberbullying. These policies prohibit discrimination, intimidation, harassment and bullying based on the actual or perceived characteristics set forth in Sections 422.55 and 220 of the Penal Code, and disability, gender, gender identity, gender expression, nationality, race or ethnicity, religion, sexual orientation, or association with a person or group with one or more of these actual or perceived characteristics.
		 
The District has adopted a process for receiving and investigating complaints of this nature as well as including bullying prevention strategies in the comprehensive safety plans.  In addition, staff and administration have received professional development training related to student discipline and bullying.
		 
District Initiatives:
All school administrators were provided with training materials on how to identify when bullying is taking place and ways to intervene.  The administrators then used these materials to provide training to all staff.
Some schools have conducted school-wide lessons with students so that they understand how devastating bullying is and how they can prevent or intervene when bullying occurs.
An anonymous hotline for each school is available for students and/or parents to report bullying incidents.
Administrators and support staff received training from legal counsel, Dora J. Dome, regarding the latest procedures in due process and the new requirements under Assembly Bill 9.
Associate Principals also received training from JoAnn Allen, Santa Cruz COE Safe Schools Coordinator, in bullying laws and changing the culture and climate in schools.
Each school site will participate in the WeTip anonymous crime reporting hotline program that students can call to report crime or bullying incidents.  All calls are confidential.  Literature includes posters, brochures and cards related to bullying, graffiti and other crimes.
The attached presentation outlines school initiated efforts.
		 
Education Code and Board Policies continue to be updated to comply with legislation.

Item:  12.03
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services, and Kirsten King, Director of Instructional Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation and/or Discussion regarding the Student Achievement Report
	 
East Side Union High School District students in grades 9 -11 took the State Mandated California Standards Tests (CST) and the California High School Exit Exam.  Together these assessments make up the elements of the Accountability Reporting System:  Academic Performance Index (API), Adequate Yearly Progress (AYP), and Program Improvement (PI).  This report contains information on how students and subgroups of students performed on these tests.  The report, also shows student progress in Physical Fitness exams.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item:  12.04
		 
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services, and Kirsten King, Director of Instructional Services
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Presentation and/or Discussion regarding the Plan to Utilize Common Core State Funds 
		 
The State of California is allocating funds to assist districts in the implementation of Common Core State Standards.  The money will come in two installments and districts must have a board approved plan for spending the money.  The funds can only be spent in three areas, technology, instructional materials, and professional development.  The plan must be submitted to the board for review and an accompanying public hearing must be held.  The board can not act on or approve the plan until the next regular board meeting.
		 
As a condition of receiving these funds the district will have to expend the funds by June 30, 2015.  On or before July 1, 2015, the district will have to report detailed expenditure information to the State Department of Education, including, but not limited to, specific purchases made and the number of teachers, administrators, or paraprofessional educators that received professional development.  The State Department of Education will be determining the format for this report.
       
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
One time Restricted State Funds
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Projected - 4.7 Million

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  12.05
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services, and Tim Nguyen, Coordinator of English Language Learners Supplementary Education
					 
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Receive Third Valenzuela/CAHSEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaint Quarterly Report for Period Covering July 1, 2013  through September 30, 2013 as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727)
	 
	 
Background
As a result of the Williams Case (EC 35186), referred to as a landmark Superior Court case requires that every California public school provide each student with, at the very least, sufficient textbooks and instructional materials; clean, safe and functional buildings and facilities; and permanent, appropriately trained and assigned teachers.  Additionally, under the settlement of the Valenzuela/CAHSEE Settlement (EC 37254) students in grades 10 to 12 inclusive shall be notified of services available to students up to two consecutive years after the completion of grade 12 who have not yet passed the CAHSEE.
	 
School districts shall support summarized data on the nature and resolution of all Williams Complaints and Valenzuela/CAHSEE Complaints on a quarterly basis to the governing board and the county superintendent of schools.  The report shall include the number of complaints by the general subject area with the number of resolved and unresolved complaints.
	 
The attached report indicates the number of complaints filed from July 1, 2013 through September 30, 2013.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
None
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Senate Bill 6 (Williams)
State Instructional Materials Allocation
District Instructional Materials Budget
Other Categorical funds as Appropriate
	 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees accept the Third Quarterly Valenzuela/CAHSEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaint report for the period covering July 1, 2013 through September 30 2013, as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727).

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item:  13.01
		 
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, Cari Vaeth, Director of Human Resources, and Karen Poon, Director of Finance
					 
					 
REVIEWED BY:
Kelly Kwong, Senior Manager of Internal Controls
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action Regarding Capital Program Reorganization
		 
		 
In the Bond Program Performance Audit Report dated September 13, 2013, Total School Solutions commended the District for its positive actions in regard to the following:
bond revenue management
diligence in taxpayer obligations through debt restructuring activities
leveraging of bond funds through aggressive pursuit of State grant funds under the School Facility Program
response to issues raised in the 2010 FCMAT Extraordinary Audit
development of bond project scopes, budgets and schedules
faithful execution of the Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee’s duties and responsibilities
The Performance Audit also identified several weaknesses in the District’s conduct of its program, including:
excess staffing attributable to some duplication of work effort
financial management discrepancies
the approach to change orders
District Administration proposes a reorganization of its capital construction program to address the staffing and financial management weaknesses cited in the Performance Audit.  The reorganization proposal includes creation of a new Capital Accounting Department which would create three and one half (3.5) new positions to provide bond program financial management; two (2) new positions would be added to expand Capital Purchasing to provide vendor relations, qualifications and evaluations, and comprehensive capital purchasing duties in addition to the contract administration and labor compliance work currently being performed; and creation of one (1) new position in the Information Technology Department to provide bond program and facilities technology implementation and support.  The total number of positions to be added is six and one half (6.5), of which four and one half (4.5) would be CSEA positions and two (2) would be classified management positions.
		 
This reorganization will provide clarity of roles and responsibilities which have historically resulted in program inefficiencies.  In addition, the enhanced implementation of technology will automate activities that have historically been performed manually, resulting in labor savings, time efficiencies, especially mitigating information disparities.  While providing overall improvement in quality, this reorganization will also realize a $1.3 million annual cost savings in comparison to what the District currently pays to have these services performed by the Program Manager.  
		 
The Senior Manager of Internal Controls reviewed Bond Program Management service fees.  The review covered Program Management contracts for Bond Measure E dated September 2008, amended December 2011, February 2013, and June 2013, as well as expenditures realized from inception November 2008 through August 2013.  The Senior Manager of Internal Controls concludes that program management service fees paid through August 2013 of $12.2M exceeds the 5% maximum total program budget as defined as $11.1M.  If the Board-Cabinet Contingency is released, the limit is redefined as $12.2M.  Expected fees through October 2013 are $12.7M which exceeds both defined limits.
		 
The reorganization of the capital program will reduce the scope of contracted program management services to four (4) FTE from the current level which has been as high as thirteen (13) FTE.  The Measure E average monthly program management expenses total about $260,000 per month and the program has an estimated completion date of May 2015.  Based on our estimates, the District would incur a cost of almost $4.5 million over and above the 5% maximum if the program remains as is.
		 
The District’s Senior Manager of Internal Controls reviewed this proposed capital program reorganization, verified and concurs with the cost savings analysis.
		 
A detailed description of the capital program reorganization is presented for discussion and approval (Attachment A), as well as the District’s report from the Senior Manager of Internal Controls regarding total program management fees and associated savings from reorganization  (Attachment B).
		 
		 
Fiscal Impact:
($1,300,000 annual savings)
		 
Funding Source:
Bond Measures G, E and I
		 
Recommendation:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the capital program reorganization.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the capital program reorganization.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item:  13.02
		 
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Dale Scott, Financial Advisor, Dale Scott & Company, and Charles F. Adams, Bond Counsel, Jones Hall
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Adopt Resolution #2013/2014-10 Adopting Policies with Respect to the Issuance of Capital Appreciation Bonds     
		 
		 
At an election held on November 6, 2012, the voters of the District approved a ballot measure (Measure I) authorizing the issuance of general obligation bonds in the principal amount of $120 million.  The vote was held pursuant to Proposition 39, which required at least a 55% approval rate for passage, with the actual passage rate being 71.5%.  The Board has previously adopted its Resolutions on August 22 and September 19, 2013 authorizing the issuance and terms of the first series of bonds under Measure I.
		 
The Santa Clara County Civil Grand Jury has recently filed its Final Report with the Board relating to the issuance of Capital Appreciation Bonds (“CABs”) by school districts.  CABs are a specific type of bond, whereby the interest on the bond compounds to the final maturity date.  The Grand Jury Report recommended restricting the usage of CABs in any new bond issuance.  
		 
Recently, the California State Legislature passed Assembly Bill 182 (“AB 182”), which implements specific restrictions on the ability of school districts to use CABs.  The new law is effective January 1, 2014.
		 
The Board is required to respond to the Grand Jury Report.  The purpose of the new proposed Board Resolution is to formally adopt the findings and recommendations of the Grand Jury Report including the provisions set forth under AB 182, effectively implementing the restrictions on CABs now, rather than waiting until the January 1, 2014 effective date.
		 
The adoption of the resolution will not impact the bonds to be issued under Measure I since capital appreciation bonds were not authorized in either of the Board’s prior resolutions.
		 
		 
Fiscal Impact:
Not Applicable
		 
Funding Source:
Not Applicable
		 
Recommendation:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the adoption of Resolution #2013/2014-10 Adopting Policies with Respect to the Issuance of Capital Appreciation Bonds.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  15.01
	 
	 
TO:
  Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:
  Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, Kenneth Kerch, AIA, SGI Bond Program Manager, and Mike Van Pelt, Van Pelt Construction Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation and Discussion on the Lease Leaseback Delivery Method for Modernization Projects at Independence High School
	 
	 
The District’s Capital Improvement Program is a complex portfolio of projects, spanning multiple years and funded by local general obligation bond measures G, E and I, Office of Public School Construction (OPSC) school facility program grants, and other minor funding streams.  A robust capital construction program of this nature should include consideration and use of a number of project delivery methods, including Lease Leaseback.  
	 
The Lease Leaseback delivery method is implemented as follows:
	 
The District contracts with the architect, who with their team of engineering subconsultants produces a complete set of DSA approved construction documents
Concurrently, the District selects a contractor based on qualifications, not low bid
Through a Preconstruction Agreement, the contractor has early involvement with design and engineering through incremental constructability reviews and value engineering
The District enters into a Site Lease with the contractor, which terminates when the Facilities Lease terminates.
The contractor competitively bids subcontract work, provides a guaranteed maximum price, and enters into a Facilities Lease with District.  The contractor constructs the facility, leases the facility back to the District, and transfers title of the facility to the District upon final payment.
	 
The Lease Leaseback delivery method benefits the District in a variety of aspects:
There are generally fewer change orders due to unforeseen conditions because the contractor can perform destructive testing and exploration of existing conditions during preconstruction, and those conditions can be incorporated by the architect into the construction plans and specifications.  In addition, constructability reviews by the contractor during the preconstruction period can reveal non-constructible details or details requiring clarification, reducing the quantity of Requests for Information and associated delays and change orders during construction.  As with any delivery method, the District remains responsible for change orders due to site conditions and Owner-initiated changes.
There is greater price certainty as the project enters the construction phase, as the contractor offers a guaranteed maximum price when entering into the Facilities Lease. 
Reduced administrative and soft costs
There is some transference of design risk to the contractor, due to the contractor providing assistance via the Preconstruction Agreement that results in a guaranteed maximum price at the onset of construction.
The contractor is selected based on qualifications and best value, not based on the lowest bid.  This selection process allows the District and its architect to work with a contracting team that is committed to identifying a fair scope of work within the District’s construction budget.  Team efforts are spent productively advancing the project, rather than positioning into the adversarial relationships normally associated with the traditional public works delivery method.
The contractor can negotiate subcontracts, so the District can benefit from reliable subcontractors.
The District receives the benefit of reduced project delivery time, due to nonlinear construction procurement.
Early involvement of contractors adds construction practicality to design imagination.
	 
The Lease Leaseback delivery method has been widely used in recent years and is growing in popularity among progressive and quality-oriented Districts.  Final construction cost will be similar to a project that has been traditionally bid; but the process is inherently teamwork oriented, and provides greater ability to identify affordable design solutions earlier.  Historically, the Lease Leaseback delivery method has experienced fewer claims and disputes because the contractor has had early involvement.  
	 
District administration, the bond program manager and the Independence High School construction management team have identified the Lease Leaseback delivery method as the best way to bring a contractor on board for the modernizations of the Theater, the B Commons, Streetscape Improvements, and Infrastructure Upgrades.  The District will be able to retain contractors who are uniquely qualified for the varied scopes of work of these projects, accelerate the schedule, manage risk, and have early cost control.  The team will give a presentation that offers insight into their strategy, and the associated procurement logistics and schedule (Attachment A).

Item:  15.02
	 
	 
TO:
  Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:
  Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, and Kenneth Kerch, AIA, SGI Bond Program Manager
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action on the Update of the Bond Program
	 
	 
In 2002, voters in the East Side Union High School District approved Bond Measure G in the amount of $298 million for the purpose of modernizing existing school facilities and building new facilities to support the changing needs of K-12 education in the District. A substantial portfolio of projects has been completed under Measure G, which is concluding with a district-wide site improvement initiative, currently underway.
	 
In 2008, voters in the District approved Bond Measure E in the amount of $349 million for the purpose of continuing modernization of existing school facilities and building of new facilities to support the changing needs of K-12 education in the District. To date, 41 Measure E projects have been completed, 10 are in bid/design, and 8 are under construction.
	 
In 2012, voters in the District approved Bond Measure I in the amount of $120 million for the purpose of continuing modernization of existing school facilities and building of new facilities to support the changing needs of K-12 education in the District. Planning is in progress to identify the projects to be completed with Measure I funds.
	 
An update on the status of the District’s bond program is presented for discussion (Attachment A).

Not Applicable

Not Applicable

Not Applicable

Item:  15.03
			 
			 
TO:
  Board of Trustees
						 
						 
FROM:
  Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Adopt Resolution #2013/2014-08 To Certify Housing and Community Relocatable Buildings at Overfelt Adult Education Center Are No Longer Being Used as School Buildings
			 
			 
Senate Bill 1469 (Chapter 747, Statutes of 2000) provided that certain relocatable buildings with a commercial coach insignia of approval from the Department of Housing and Community Development (HCD) could continue to be used for school purposes if they were retrofitted in accordance with stated requirements. The Bill required school districts to certify to the Division of the State Architect that these HCD buildings comply with the requirements, and, thus, could continue to be used for school purposes until a specified period of time.
			 
Subsequent legislation, SB 1324 (Chapter 308, Statutes of 2006), requires the governing board of the school district to adopt a resolution by October 30, 2015, certifying to the State Allocation Board that commencing September 30, 2015, these HCD buildings are no longer being used as school buildings.
			 
The Overfelt Adult Education (OAE) program relocated into their newly constructed permanent building in June 2013, and subsequently nine HCD-type relocatable buildings were removed from the OAE site in July 2013.  The Board can adopt Resolution 2013/14-08 certifying that those nine buildings are no longer being used as school buildings.
			 
			 
Fiscal Impact:
Not applicable
			 
			 
Funding Source:
Not applicable
			 
			 
Recommendation:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution #2013/2014-08 to certify Housing and Community Development (HCD) relocatable buildings formerly located at the Overfelt Adult Education site are no longer being used as school buildings.

Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action of Proposed Cost Sharing of White Road Street Lighting Upgrade Project
			 
			 
The City of San Jose Department of Transportation is proposing a street lighting upgrade project along White Road between Alum Rock and Gay Avenues.  Refer to the attached document for a graphical depiction of scope and location (Attachment A).  The scope of work includes installation of 19 new “white” LED lights and the conversion of 13 existing “yellow” lights to LED’s.
			 
Based on jurisdictional/frontage location of the proposed lights, the improvement would benefit the City of San Jose, James Lick High School (JLHS) and the County of San Clara.  There are currently only 2 street lights near the White Road/Alum Rock corner along the JLHS frontage, so the additional street lights would improve night time appearance and safety, making JLHS more attractive and helping to improve student recruitment and retention.  LED lights provide superior lighting optics, are energy efficient and modern; they are a prudent choice for street lighting.
			 
The Department of Transportation estimates the project to cost $320,000, and proposes a commensurate cost sharing arrangement, as follows:

The cost share estimate was developed based on jurisdictional/frontage responsibility and using current pricing from the City’s LED fixture purchase agreement.  If for any reason the material costs change, the cost share will be increased or decreased based on actuals.  However, the labor portion (engineering, inspection and construction) would stay fixed as proposed as these do not fluctuate based on material costs.
			 
City of San Jose will manage the project and fund ongoing street light energy and maintenance.

Not to exceed $112,000
			 
Funding Source:
Capital Facilities Fund 35
			 
Recommendation:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve participation in the City of San Jose’s White Road street lighting upgrade initiative and authorize the Associate Superintendent to enter into an agreement with the City of San Jose, at a not to exceed cost of $112,000.

Item:  15.08
			 
			 
TO:
  Board of Trustees
						 
						 
FROM:
  Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, and Janice Unger, Capital Projects Purchasing Manager
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Extend Measure E Program Management Agreement with Seville Group Inc.
			 
			 
Seville Group, Inc. (“SGI”) provides program management services to the District in connection with the District’s Measure E Bond Program.  SGI’s program management agreement with the District expires on October 31, 2013.  The Administration is preparing a recommendation to the Board for program management services for the District’s Measure G, Measure E and Measure I Bond Programs.
			 
The program management agreement provides in pertinent part that the program manager’s fee “shall not exceed 5.0 percent (5%) of $349,000,000 or 5% of the maximum total PROGRAM [Measure E] budget through June 30, 2016 as authorized at any time by the DISTRICT’S Board of Trustees . . . whichever is less”, subject to certain exclusions specified in the agreement.  Staff and SGI are currently reconciling total fees paid under the agreement and application of the 5% cap; staff calculates that total fees are at or are about to exceed the 5% cap whereas SGI calculates the 5% cap is not yet impaired.  Administration believes this issue will be clarified and resolved by October 31, 2013.
			 
Administration is recommending a month-to-month extension of the Measure E program management agreement with SGI, not to extend beyond February 28, 2014, without further Board approval, to allow sufficient time for completion of the Administration’s review, analysis and recommendation to the Board.  Administration is also requesting that the Board approve a change order in an amount not exceed $625,000.00 under the amended and restated program management agreement and delegate authority to the Superintendent and  the Associate Superintendent of Business Services to authorize program management services but only to the extent necessary if and when the current 5% fee cap has been reached.
			 
FISCAL IMPACT:                                           
To be determined
                   
FUNDING SOURCE:
Measure E General Obligation Bond funds
			 
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees: (i) authorize a third amendment to the Measure E amended and restated program management agreement with SGI to extend the agreement on a month-to-month basis, but not to extend beyond February 28, 2014, without further Board approval, and (ii) authorize a change order not to exceed $625,000.00 under the amended and restated program management agreement and delegate authority to the Superintendent and  the Associate Superintendent of Business Services to authorize program management services up to that amount but only to the extent necessary if and when the current 5% fee cap has been reached.

SUBJECT:
Accept Warrant Register for the Month of September 2013   
			 
Attached is a list of warrants issued during the month of September 2013, in response to Board Policy 3314 Payment for Goods and Services adopted by the Board in May 2009.  The Policy states that, "The Board shall approve all warrants (checks) at a regularly scheduled Board meeting".  While there is no legal requirement for Board approval of issued warrants, this list and future lists will add to the "transparency" of when the Board approves purchase orders, contracts and other authorized expenses as per Board Policies.

Not Applicable
			 
Funding Source:
Not Applicable

It is recommended that the Board of Trustees accept the Warrant Register as presented for the month of September 2013.
